fdd:description.p: Storage Networking Industry Association (SNIA), in the conference paper, Towards SIRF: Self- Contained Information Retention Format, defines SIRF as a logical container format appropriate for long-term storage of digital information. It is described as the digital equivalent of collecting a group of related items, placing them into a physical box, and labeling the box with information about the contents.

SNIA is a global, non-profit organization that is the "recognized and trusted authority for storage leadership, standards, and technology expertise worldwide." SIRF was developed by the SNIA Long Term Retention (LTR) Technical Working Group (TWG). The SNIA website states, "The SIRF format enables long-term physical storage, cloud storage and tape-based containers effective and efficient ways to preserve and secure digital information for many decades, even with the ever-changing technology landscape."

SNIA Technical Position specifies SIRF Level 1 "and its serialization for LTFS, CDMI and OpenStack Swift." Users can find the SNIA SIRF Specification Version 1.0 on their website. SIRF components and use cases are defined in the SNIA document, SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements, Working Draft, published September 2010. The format is also documented as an International Organization for Standardization (ISO) specification, ISO/IEC 23681, published May 2019.

As describe in the SNIA document, SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements, moving complete digital content between systems and technologies in the future will be easier with a standard that has these key properties:

ul.li: Self-contained - object data and its metadata are treated and moved together as a single storable unit; object's container should include metadata about interrelationship between the object(s) and the metadata about the object(s).

Self-describing - interpret the data package correctly; determine container object(s) and their associated metadata.
"Self-describing formats remain useful if at the root of the recursion they use only very widely used formats, such as ASCII, and the self-description itself can be updated over time. While it is possible to create self-describing proprietary formats, widely used industry standard formats are more likely to have a long life."
Extensible - allows for addition and extensions while preserving integrity of original data.

fdd:description.p: SIRF is a "logical data format of a mountable unit e.g., a filesystem, a block device, a stream device, an object store, a tape, etc. It assumes the mountable unit includes an object interface layer that constructs objects out of the sectors and blocks."
According to the SIRF Standard, SIRF has the following components:

ul.li:
Magic object:
The magic object identifies the container and its version.
Independent of the media, it has an agreed defined name and a fixed size.
Has means to access the SIRF catalog.

Preservation Objects (PO):
Contains the actual data to be preserved.
May include multiple versions of objects and multiple copies of each version.
SIRF Standard does not specify POs format, generally created by the application/service outside the storage subsystem.

A Catalog:
That is updatable and contains metadata for the container and its objects to be portable/accessible in future without relying on external metadata.
"The SIRF catalog is an object that includes metadata about the Preservation Objects (POs) in the container and their relationship. It has a well-defined standardized format so it can be understandable in the future."
The catalog contains metadata for both the whole container and the preservation objects within the container. Both types are organized into categories. See Adoption for more information.

fdd:description.p: The SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements states, "SIRF is scoped to define the metadata and format in its catalog, which includes information about the preservation objects, the relationship among these objects and information to support implementation of preservation processes."
The SIRF Standard provides the conditions to be met for CDMI/LTFS/Swift containers to qualify as a SIRF container.

ul.li:
Cloud Data Management Interface (CDMI):
ISO/IEC 17826 Standard - interoperable format for moving data and metadata between cloud providers, defines a RESTful Interface - data objects are accessed by standard browsers/internet tools.
It has an open-source implementation on top of OpenStack Swift.
Qualified SIRF container adds Extension specification defining the new field for cloud support.
Serialization: SIRF magic object mapped to CDMI container metadata, SIRF catalog is an object in CDMI container, SIRF PO simple object mapped to CDMI data object, SIRF PO composite object mapped to set of data objects/manifest data object.

Linear Tape File System (LTFS):
Format Specification Defines LTFS Volumes - holds data files and metadata describing the directory and file structures stored on the volume.
Files are written to and read from LTFS Volume using POSIX file operations.
LTFS Volume includes XML index with metadata, such as file name, dates, extended attributes, etc.
LTFS Volume is partitioned - Data Partition and Index Partition, each containing a label construct followed by content area.
Serialization: SIRF magic object mapped to extended attributes "LTFS index" root directory, SIRF catalog is within index partition, PO mapped to LTFS file/set of files.

OpenStack Swift:
Object/blob store in the cloud.
Uses a RESTful interface for creation, manipulation, and deletion of objects/metadata.
Serialization: SIRF objects mapped to Swift objects, SIRF containers mapped to Swift containers, magic object is included in Swift container's metadata, catalog mapped to a file in container, PO mapped to Swift objects in container and referenced in catalog.

fdd:description.p: As described in the conference paper, Towards SIRF: Self-Contained Information Retention Format, the Long Term Retention (LTR) working group created the SIRF standard format to be a "vendor-neutral storage format that will help its customers interpret preservation objects in the future, even by systems and applications that do not exist today. SIRF provides strong encapsulation of large quantities of metadata with the data at the storage level, and enables easy migration of the preserved data across storage devices...SIRF is agnostic to the type of storage medium as well as to any type of data."
SIRF's self-describing and self-contained container makes it useful for offline storage media, as well as storage that remains online.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Self-Container Information Retention Format (SIRF) is defined by Storage Networking Industry Association (SNIA) as a logical container format appropriate for long-term storage of digital information.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: May be used at any lifecycle phase, but predominantly middle state (archiving) as a container for long-term storage of digital information.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: SIRF Standard, "The SIRF catalog is an object in the CDMI container formatted in JSON." SIRF Standard, Serialization for OpenStack Swift, "The catalog is mapped to a file in JSON format (ECMA-404 The JSON Data Interchange Standard) in the container."

SIRF Standard, "A LTFS tape container can be qualified also as a SIRF container when...the SIRF catalog resides in the index partition and formatted in XML." As stated in ISO/IEC 20919:2021 | Information technology - Linear Tape File System (LTFS) Format Specification, String Format, "A character string encoded using UTF-8 in NFC. The string shall only contain characters allowed in element values by the W3C Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0 specification."

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: The Library of Congress has not yet expressed any format preference for bundling formats.

fdd:disclosure.p: Open source and documented standard. As described on the SNIA website, Self-Contained Information Retention Format (SIRF) is cataloged as a Completed Standard (mature standards with no current active development). SIRF is an SNIA Standard, "OpenSIRF is the open-source implementation of the SIRF format available under the MIT license."

Self-contained Information Retention Format (SIRF) v1.0 has been published as an International Organization Standardization (ISO) standard as of May 2019, ISO/IEC 23681:2019 | Information Technology - Self-Contained Information Retention Format (SIRF) Specification. The Standard states, "This document was prepared by SNIA (as SIRF Specification V1.0) and drafted in accordance with its editorial rules. It was adopted, under the JTC 1 PAS procedure, by Joint Technical Committee ISO/ IEC JTC 1, Information technology."

fdd:documentation.p: ISO/IEC 23681:2019 | Information technology - Self-contained Information Retention Format (SIRF) Specification (https://www.iso.org/standard/76648.html)

ul.li: Downloadable ISO/IEC 23681:2019 PDF link. (https://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/c076648_ISO_IEC_23681_2019(E).zip)

fdd:adoption.p: SNIA's conference paper, Towards SIRF: Self-Contained Information Retention Format, states, SIRF "can by mapped to and physically migrated between a wide variety of underlying storage systems."

The SIRF Standard states, "A SIRF-compliant CDMI container, LTFS Tape or Swift container enables future CDMI/LTFS/Swift clients "understand" containers created by today's CDMI/LTFS/Swift clients although the properties of the future client is unknown to us today. By 'understand', it means that clients can identify the preservation objects in the container, the packaging format of each object, its fixity values, etc. (as defined in the SIRF catalog)."

According to Stephen Pritchard in ComputerWeekly.com's feature article, Indefinite Storage: What It Is and Why You Might Need It, November 2022, "The industry has developed common formats, such as PDF/A (which dates back to 2005) and self- declaratory data, such as the Self-Contained Information Retention Format, or SIRF. These data formats allow for software obsolescence. Chief information officers can exploit the fact that storing data for longer is becoming easier."

HPSS Storage Broker: interface built for long-lived data, as described in the HPSS- Collaboration.org's document, "Storage Broker employs Open Archival Information System (OAIS) concepts for digital archives by storing archived data as self-describing, self-contained, data containers using the SNIA Self-contained Information Retention Format (SIRF). Storage Broker SIRF-based preservation container format and archive strategy allows institutions to organize their long-lived data for future generations.
Roger Cummings describes SIRF in the SNIA document, Long Term Retention Work @ SNIA, "SIRF Implementations will leverage other standards," including:

ul.li:
Open Archival Information System (OAIS) ISO standard>:
Standard defines OAIS reference model, "An OAIS is an archive, consisting of an organization, which may be part of a larger organization, of people and systems that has accepted the responsibility to preserve information and make it available for a designated community."
SNIA Long Term Retention for Medical AI Applications document describes the SIRF format and its components, stating, "SIRF is inspired by the Open Archival Information System (OAIS) - ISO 14721:2003...SIRF defines a preservation object based on OAIS."

Network Attached Storage (NFS/CIFS):
Network-Attached Storage Wikipedia describes NFS as, "file-level (as opposed to block-level storage) computer data storage server connected to a computer network providing data access to a heterogeneous group of clients."

XAM (Extensible Access Method):
SNIA XAM Interface specification defines XAM as the "standard access method (API) between 'Consumers' (application and management software) and 'Providers' (storage systems) to manage fixed content reference information storage services."
Per SNIA SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements, 2010, "XAM can be used to provide an object interface for SIRF, and the XAM interface can be used to access the SIRF container and the contained preservation objects."

fdd:licensingAndPatents.p: Per SNIA SIRF Specification Usage Section describes permissions for individuals, corporations, and other business entities to use the document, including personal use, internal use, and what conditions must be adhered to.
The SIRF Specification states, "All code fragments, scripts, data tables, and sample code in this SNIA document are made available under the following license:

ul.li: BSD 3-Clause Software License Copyright (c) 2016, The Storage Networking Industry Association."

fdd:licensingAndPatents.p: The SIRF Standard states that some of the elements in the Standard may be subject to patent rights, but "ISO and IEC shall not be held responsible for identifying any or all such patent rights."
Users may visit the ISO list of Patent Declarations Received (see https://www.iso.org/iso-standards-and-patents.html) or the IEC list of Patent Declarations Received (see http://patents.iec.ch).

fdd:transparency.p: As stated in the SIRF Standard, "Creating and maintaining the SIRF catalog requires executing data-intensive computations on the various preservation objects... This can be done efficiently via executing computational modules - storlets - close to where the data is stored... The Storlet Engine is an engine to support such storlets computations in secure sandboxes within the storage system, and can be used to create and maintain SIRF containers."

ul.li:
According to IBM Research, Storlet Engine: Performing Computations in Cloud Storage describes the Storlet Engine as "an engine to support computations in secure sandboxes within the cloud storage."
OpenStack defines storlets as "complied and packaged code (e.g., a .jar file) that can be uploaded to Swift as any other object. Once uploaded the storlet can be invoked over data objects in Swift."

fdd:transparency.p: SIRF catalog is object in CDMI container formatted in JSON.

SNIA's CDMI 2.0 Extensions lists the JSON Transfer Encoding extension, stating, "CDMI 1.0.2 supports two transfer encodings, UTF-8 and Base64. UTF-8 works well for text, but requires all JSON special characters (such as quotes ") to be escaped. Base64 works well for binary data, and does not require any special escaping, but is not human readable."
SIRF catalog resides in index partition, formatted in XML.
According to SNIA's LTFS Format Specification, "The Index is an XML document conforming to the XML schema."

SIRF catalog is mapped to file in JSON format, ECMA-404 The JSON Data Interchange Standard. ECMA-404 states, "JSON is a lightweight, text-based, language-independent syntax for defining data interchange formats."

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: Supports the inclusion of metadata in the catalog.
The SIRF Standard describes the metadata categories of both the whole container and the POs within the container.
Metadata included in Whole Container Categories:

ul.li:
Container Information:
Specification, Container ID, State, Provenance, Audit Log.
Objects Sets (metadata for all POs set).

Object Information (metadata for each PO).
Object IDs, Related Objects, Dates, Packaging Format, Fixity, Retention, Audit Log, Extension.

fdd:selfDocumentation.p: SIRF Standard describes specific metadata units in the various categories and provides a hierarchical representation of the metadata units, based on PREservation Metadata: Implementation, Strategies (PREMIS) when possible.

fdd:externalDependencies.p: None. As described in Towards SIRF: Self-Contained Information Retention Format, SIRF was created as a standardized vendor-neutral storage format.

fdd:compress.p: As stated in the SIRF Standard, SIRF POs can have different packaging formats within the SIRF container, the Packaging Format Category is used to indicate what format is used, e.g., PREMIS, XIP, XFDU. There is one element in this category, Packaging Format Name, defined as "a string that represents the format of the PO including format version. The string may also include the compression algorithm name if the PO is compressed."

fdd:error.p: SNIA's SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements describes the SIRF levels, stating "SIRF is defined using a layered approach with two levels. The SIRF level 1 catalog contains unique metadata that is not included within the preservation objects, but is mandatory to make those preservation objects portable into the future...The SIRF level 2 catalog includes information that may also be included within the preservation objects but is needed for fast access to the preservation objects."

ul.li: Level 1 Examples: Fixity algorithms, fixity values, fixity calculation dates, etc.
Level 2 Examples: Referential integrity, metadata about packaging format, etc.

fdd:history.p: SNIA, registered as a 501(c) non-profit. was established in 1997 and is a worldwide trusted authority for "all things storage." It is comprised of 200 industry leading organizations and has 2,500 active contributing members. The SNIA website states, "As a recognized and trusted authority for storage leadership, standards, and technology expertise worldwide, SNIA's mission is to lead the storage industry in developing and promoting vendor-neutral architectures, standards, and educational services that facilitate the efficient management, movement, and security of information."

SNIA's SIRF Use Cases and Functional Requirements document was published on September 27, 2010, followed by the conference paper Towards SIRF: Self-Contained Information Retention Format in May 2011. SIRF Specification V1.0 was prepared by SNIA and published December 7, 2016, with the ISO adopting the specification under the JTC 1 PAS procedure, by Joint Technical Committee ISO/ IEC JTC 1, Information technology, ISO/IEC 23681, in 2019.
